segments.text: You're going to have trouble with that.
That's something they can see.
And they did.
But actually it turned out that the fishermen learned that the area where they had been dumping this acid was known as the acid ground and was a very good area to fish in.
So I haven't heard from that for quite a long time.
So you primarily raised funds in from private sources here during the war for biology, or after the war.
Excuse me.
Primarily then you have private funds coming in for your work right after the war.
Very small, relatively speaking.
But that was all they had to run the biology on, that and a little bit of the institution.
And that held on for...
where it really held on for the rest of my time, which ended in 1956 when I retired.
Now the National Science Foundation has taken over and gives very large grants for biology.
That was not true then, sir.
What?
That was not true then.
What sort of biology are you working on between 1945 and 1956?
Well, it was this problem of pollution.
We worked for the National Lid Company, as I told you.
Then the next job was for a group that were building a great trunk sewer down the Raritan Valley.
The Raritan Valley had become a great industrialized area.
It had grown very rapidly.
And the little local sewers were inadequate to take care of.
And so they conceived the idea of all getting together and building a trunk sewer down to the head of Raritan Bay and dumping it into the Raritan Bay.
And we were engaged to study Raritan Bay in that connection.
Then the oyster industry in Great South Bay had difficulty.
And they engaged us in some of the local towns, Islip and
and so engaged us to study the pollution of Laritan Bay by duck farms.
And what did you discover in that?
Did it affect the oysters?
Oh, it absolutely ruined the oyster industry.
I don't believe there's an oyster raised in Great South Bay anymore.
The famous Blue Point oyster.
Yeah.
Blue Point is in Laritan Bay.
But the viewpoint oysters now all come from either Long Island Sound or New Jersey or somewhere else.
The oysters simply stopped feeding on this water and soared to death and became nothing but so much water.
What was Columbus Island like to work for?
Oh, he was very easy to work for.
What sort of man was he?
I think Roger has just written a memoir about him.
I remember he's consulting me, and I tell him.
Roger's insistence insists that
Columbus and Henry Bigelow were amateurs.
I think it's a little bit overdrawn there.
I think I would shade him down a bit.
But as you know, he was a man, I would say that he was born into a wealthy family.
I don't know how wealthy or whether it was great wealth or moderate wealth, but
I don't think he ever worried very much about how he earned his living.
And he went to Harvard.
His family background was in banking.
And he assumed as a young man, or as a boy, that he was going to become a banker.
So he specialized in mathematics.
I don't think he ever did any really mathematical work, except not original work, at any rate.
the calculations he had to make for his Gulf Stream currents and so on were based on mathematical ideas, but they weren't his ideas.
He was following well-laid-down prescriptions.
But he was also brought up on the water at the head of Long Island Sound and was a very good sailor.
And while he was in college, he got hold of a ship, a schooner, and made a cruise to Labrador.
And he thought, well, possibly he could do some scientific work on this cruise.
So he went to see Professor Bigelow, who was at Harvard, who was the fish expert and the jellyfish expert, essentially, but who had been doing this work in the Gulf of Maine.
And Bigelow helped him get some apparatus and told him what to do.
And then he went back and became Bigelow's student.
He never took his doctor's degree at Harvard or anywhere else.
He never thought his work was worth it.
He didn't.
And that sort of shows how naive one can be and how naive students are about the doctor's thesis.
Yes.
You probably have that problem in history also.
We do indeed have that problem in history, believe me.
Yes.
How was the institution changing in the 50s while you were here?
Was there an influx of new people?
Did it seem to change in a new direction?
Well, it has grown, of course, tremendously.
It has changed because the board of directors, the board of trustees,
are no longer scientists.
They are predominantly successful administrators of business.
And they're a very fine lot of fellows, and very wise, I think, probably.
But there are practically no scientists amongst them.
Or if they have been scientists, it's so remote.
And there certainly are no oceanographers amongst them.
Now, originally, particularly during this period, immediately after the war, the trustees were people like Aethels and Spielhaus, Brian Wilson, Detlef Planck.
Well, that's enough to illustrate that.
Spike Cole, and so on.
All of which were scientists, most of which had worked in Woods Hole.
And those trustees meetings used to be damn good fun, because these fellows knew each other very well.
They fought amongst one another.
You had wonderful arguments about every question that came up.
Now the trustees meetings are so dull that
I decide I won't go to them, and I usually do go.
But we all sit in a big room, and we hear the director read a report on the wonderful things the institution is doing.
Of course it's wonderful.
He wouldn't say it otherwise.
The growth in size, the amount of money which is available, I'm simply shocked at the amount which is spent
by practically beginning people.
I have never gotten more than one grant to support my work.
When I retired, I applied for a grant for $10,000 to study salt marshes.
I suspect they were an awful long time granting that money.
I suspect they couldn't quite decide where the soil marshes fitted in.
And I spent, I suppose, 80% of that simply on having chemical analyses made for carbon-14, which we were not set up to make and which were quite expensive.
The rest were to hire boys to help me in the summer to do the heavy
helped me with the heavy work.
They have more money than that now, certainly.
They get more money than that now, certainly.
That's nothing.
I don't think they look at less than $100,000 for one year of work.
I worked for 10 years on $10,000.
You spent 10 years on the salt marshes before?
Yeah.
What did you finally publish on the salt marshes?
What was your final paper on the salt marshes?
Well, my final paper was published in 1973, I think, on the development.
When I retired in 1956,
or 55 when I was 60 or 65 years old.
I retired just as early as I could.
55 to 65 was the retirement age.
They, in exceptional cases, might ask you to stay on for an additional four years.
But I didn't want to do that.
And so I retired just as quickly as I could.
The afternoon that I finally moved my last piece of junk out of my office up here, I went over to Barnstable and tried out a piece of apparatus, which worked.
I went over the next day and tested another piece of apparatus, and it worked.
And I worked for 10 years studying the development of this marsh.
Sounds like a wonderful retirement to me.
Spend 10 years on your own work.
It was a lot of fun.
Then at the end of 10 years, when I was 75 years or more, I began to get awkward.
And I fell overboard several times.
And I realized I'd better not go out on small boats anymore.
And then some time after that, my eyes went out.
I had cataracts.
So I can't see very well.
So that's what the end of actual field work.
And so since that time, I have been working on the tides of the New England coast, which are all described in the tide tables and carefully measured in thousands of places to see.
but never put together as a whole by anybody, so far as I know.

And I have been, well, I started out with the idea of writing a book about the tides of the New England coast, which is a very interesting area because it contains illustrations of practically all the tidal phenomena which are important in the world.
And you see, we have the largest tides in the world.
We have reversing falls, so-called, at St. John and so on.
And I thought a book of that sort would be a good bit of interest and value to people who lived or spent their summers along this coast.
And there are a lot of them.
And then I found that I couldn't write that book because I couldn't put into the
into a popular book, things which the experts would not recognize and take for granted.
And so I had to write a paper for the experts, which I'm now working on.
Whether I live long enough to write the book, I don't know.
But at the moment, chances are pretty good that the experts at least will get their story.
Yeah.
Woods Hole must have been a delightful place in the 40s and 50s.
Certainly a lovely place.
Well, it was a more delightful place in the 15s and 20s.
It was, huh?
Did you ever foresee it becoming the kind of institution it became today?
Did you ever foresee it becoming the kind of institution it became today?
No.
It was just sort of a place a person went to work and enjoy.
Yes.
Oh, I knew that the MBL was a great institution, perhaps the greatest marine laboratory in the world at that time.
And it would continue to be such.
Of course, the oceanographic was an afterthought.
And I did not conceive of us becoming, receiving the support to become the large institution it now has.
What was the sort of reaction around Woods Hole the first time the big boats came in after World War II?
when the Atlantis is created and so forth for you?
Well, I don't think that Woods Hole was very much surprised by anything.
This place has been a seaport for a good many years.
You see, back in the 70s and 80s and 90s, there was the Guiano Works here, and ships came from the Pacific loaded with Guiano.
and from other parts of the world with other materials, so that they were quite used to having the biggest ships that existed at that time come into this harbor.
And then that fell through, and the laboratories came.
They operated smaller than steam ships, steamboats, boats 40, 50, 50 feet long, you see.
with little steam engines in them.
And then the Atlantis was the biggest sailing vessel, which was then built at that time.
But that wasn't so much, you know.
They were quite used to seeing large yachts go through and so on and stuff here.
And then the further additions came gradually, year after year, ship after ship, bigger and bigger.
I don't think there was any great shock involved of that sort to the community.
To the institution, what was the sort of reaction among the faculty when for the first time it was discovered you'd go out to deep sea?
When you discovered you'd go out to deep sea with vessels, what's up?
I don't quite put your question into its context.

I was thinking, what was the reaction of the older members of the faculty when it becomes apparent that with changes and innovation in oceanography, that you're going to be able to do deep sea research, just not sound and coastal?
No, in the first place, there was no faculty.
Ah, OK.
I'm in staff.
Yeah, those were the staff.
And in the second place, the Atlantis was built to do work in the open sea.
It used to regularly go to Bermuda.
It was built in Copenhagen.
It came across to somewhere south of Greenland and made a section down the center of the Atlantic to, I guess, as far as Bermuda, and then came in.
And it used to go three or four times a year to Bermuda.
And every...
it would make a cruise through the Caribbean, so that going into deep water was not a novelty to the set.
It was just a part of it all.
Ah, good.
I would like to have seen Woods Hole in 1915, 16, or 17.
I bet it was a gorgeous place.
Still is a gorgeous place.
Well, of course, in those days it was a very simple little town.
I think the streets were not paved.
Certainly only the main street was paved.
The sidewalks were not paved.
There were no curves.
Those came after or during the First World War.
And I can remember at the end of the war how much, how dressed up the town looked.
coming back and finding the curves set in, sidewalks built.
They used to be just paths through the grass where you walked along beside the dirt road.
See, that would be nice.
When you were at Harvard and came down here, was the faculty at Harvard happy that you were going to work in the lab?
Well, the faculty, as such, of course, was utterly indifferent to me.
No, there's been a long tradition at Harvard.
of working somewhere in the summer.
Professor Mark, who was quite an older member of the faculty at the time when I was a student, I suppose he was 60 years old when I was 17 or 18, you see.
He started a little laboratory in Mervilla and used to take
some of the graduate students down there every summer.
And then Dr. Parker, who was my professor, with whom I did my doctor's work, came down to Woods Hole pretty regularly and brought one or two students down with him.
So there had existed a tradition of going to someplace to work during the summer along the shore, either Bermuda or Woods Hole.
And then here it was chosen.
It must have been a marvelous relationship between Harvard and the institutions around here to come down here and work.
Well, I think the good relation is the fact that dependents are often due on the fact that there was no relation.
Harvard, you know, is somewhat sooty.
Yes.
You've heard that.
Yeah, I've heard that.
Some people have been amazed as much.
No, I remember, I forget who told me this, but at all events, someone representing the oceanographic talked to the dean at Harvard.
about credit for work at Harvard down at Woods Hole, which we were practically willing, of course, to give.
I mean, worked hard, and honestly, we were willing to say so.
It was explained to him that Harvard gave credit to the students of Professor Bigelow and Professor Redfield of Harvard, not
to the Woodsville Oceanographic Institution as such.
Do you see?
I think one of the reasons I'm not very sympathetic with the modern development here, with the formalization of education, for example, the institution granting degrees and so on,
I think that we gave every opportunity that is given today to the graduate student at Harvard or Tech or Brown or where have you who wanted to come and work with whoever was here.
It was all done on a personal basis, man to man, not institution to institution.
But then education is man to man and not institution to institution.
Nobody is educated by Harvard or Texas A&M.
Those institutions draw rather broad lines around what the man does.
But he is really educated by the staff which is picked by those institutions as individuals.
Gee, that's true.
And you always preferred it that way?
I personally have preferred it that way.
I've never greatly consulted in the matter.
Now, you're a trustee, though, aren't you?
I'm a trustee emeritus, or an honorary trustee.
I forget what they're called.
They're called different things in different places.
But essentially, all these institutions, when you get to being a trustee, they now put a retirement age, you see, on it.
And so they won't be managed by a lot of old fogies.
And then they just want to be kind to these old fellas.
And so as they kick them upstairs, they make them honorary or emeritus trustees in special class.
They send them all the notices, all the print managers, but they don't let them vote.
They don't talk.
But they don't have to do anything about the talking, because they don't let them vote.
I think you have guests who have arrived.
Yeah, that's my daughter who has driven up from New Jersey.
Oh, very good.
I will take no more of your time, but I have enjoyed meeting you.
It's one of those things I wanted to do.
So I'm glad I called you up and got a chance to come by.
I enjoyed talking to you.
I hate it just to disturb you on the phone, but I thought that was the easiest way.
Oh, yes, well, it was very convenient.
I was with Al Vine when I called over at the place and just called away.
